into your mobile applications how you can get help using them and where the source is our mobile sdks

so to start what are the mobile sdks
so the point of them is to simplify mobile to cloud development
they're they're best suited for a thick client architecture and i'll be talking about that a little bit a little bit later about what we
mean by thick line architecture and specifically for when we say mobile sdks we're talking about two distinct
sdks one for ios which we call the aws sdk for ios and one for android the aws sdk for
android for ios we support version 4.3 and above and for android we support
version 2.2 or api level eight and above um one of the one of the big points with
the mobile sdks is it can help you build a connected mobile application without a middle tier
so who should use the mobile sdks so so as i mentioned before
um they're best suited for a thick client architecture or thick client applications
and um i'm going to go into a little bit more detail in the next slide but it's for you know applications that don't want to manage a back end
or you know where you want your users making direct uh calls to the cloud or where back-end
processing isn't necessary you don't have any you know big data transactions that you
have to do or anything of that sort then then our mobile sdks really help in those and those uh type of applications
but with the number of services that we support and with aws as your back end your you know your mobile possibilities
are really limitless
so so a little bit more detail about thick client architecture on this slide you can see that i have a
representation of thin and thick client architectures on the left hand side i have then on the right hand side thick and in a
thick line architecture your devices or your you know your mobile applications are connecting
directly to aws um they're not going through any proxy as you see that on the on the thin
client uh think client side what happens in that normal environment is you you usually set up a a server or some
kind of proxy that the clients or the applications will connect to and then those
that application server will then connect to aws to get any data or to do any processes
it needs and then return the data back to the client so the nice thing with a thick client
architecture is that there's no back end it kind of simplifies your app development
and with aws as as that back end you can support millions of customers right out of the box so it's you know
the aws mobile sdks with thick line architecture help you build you know internet scale apps without
that back-end responsibility
so this is a list of the services we support within the mobile sdks we support 11
services and you can see them there and um there's a number of you know we have some of the big data
services like s3 and dynamodb as well as some you know control plane type of
services like ec2 and elastic load balancing so you have a wide spectrum of different services that we support to give you a
variety of different apps that you can you can build um so you know with lots of services means many options
also as the services evolve and change and add new apis and features we we update and
modify the the sdks so they are kept up to date with those services so as
you know s3 introduces a new a new feature the the sdks are updated uh correspondingly to give you
access to those new features so integrating the mobile sdks into your
application and we're going to see a little bit of this in the demo bob will be doing some demos for us and he'll be showing this but
for each of them we try to make the integration as simple as possible so for ios we we build a uh a single
framework that you just add to your you know your xcode project or your ios project and
that gives you access to all of the um the sdks and the services that
all of the services the sdk supports so all the functionality so it's very
easy to add you know the ios sdk to your to your project and the same for android we
offer a single jar that you can integrate into your um you know your android project and that
again gives you access to all of the services and so our goal here is to keep this as easy and as non-intrusive as possible to
you know to use our sdks within your project so next you know what kind of impact do
our sdks have on your application so specifically um in ios
since since objective-c is statically linked only the parts of the sdk that you
actually use in your application are included in your final app so if you were to download our ios
sdk you would and you would look at the framework you would see that it's 70 megabytes and your first thought might be you know i don't want a 70 megabyte
application well that's not going to happen um depending on what you use from the sdk you might only add
you know a megabyte or so or even less and and we'll see that in the demo that you can be using s3 and it doesn't bloat
your application and with android all of our we have samples
and our sdk comes with the default proguard integration to help you minimize the overall size of your app
will be using our our sdks so our sdks won't blow your bloat your application and we try to
make sure that it's as small as possible okay so next um
i wanted to talk a little bit about some different um some use cases and we're going to be showing some demos
um that you might run into in your mobile applications and how they can be solved
by using certain services so one of the things that we include with our sdks
are a number of different uh samples and articles that show you that give you
best practices and and explain how you can use the service within an ios or android application and
give you code to get you started and explain how to use it and as you can see that we have a link

but our hope is that you know we provide a number of samples and that our samples can help you jumpstart your
you know creating your mobile applications so next bomb is going to uh give us a
demo of s3

application it's only got two buttons so i'm going to first click this one to select an image
and when i select this image the application uploads the image to s3 and then shows a a dialog saying that my upload is
completed and if i clicked our second button our image is now displayed inside of our
our view controller i can go back i can select the second image i can
click our button again and our image is changed so now if we take a look at our actual
application i'd like to highlight a couple of things first thing i'd like to highlight is the
single framework that glenn mentioned earlier so this is the one framework that you'll download as part of the sdk
and that's all that's necessary to drop in in your application to enable use of all those 11 services that the ios sdk
supports then inside of our code
first thing we'll look at is the image picker delegate so this is what hap this is the uh the method or selector that's called
after we've uh selected an image from the image picker and the first thing we need to do is create a
low level service client and this is a pattern you'll see in both of the sdks and in truth most uh
all of our sdks where we create a low-level service client and this client will be used to create
to execute operations on the individual service so we provide an access and secret key
to create that client and then we call create bucket now this is not an operation you would need to do
every single time you ran this application we're just including it for sake of completeness
then i get my image data and i create an s3 put object request
and i use that image data as the data for my object that i'm going to store in s3
i then simply call s3 put object and then show the alert after the the
upload is completed now in this example that we're showing today we're actually using a synchronous mode of operation of the
sdk but in our downloads available on the website today we use best practices for doing asynchronous calls
using delegates grand central dispatch and also background threats
then for our second portion we have another s3 client our our samples that are
available with the sdk will reuse the client but in this case we're just creating one for for ease of use
and then we create an s3 get object request once we get the response from that get
object call to s3 we just simply add our image data
to our image view then finally just want to highlight that
our in finder that our application is only 1.2 megs
so as glenn mentioned earlier the entire sdk is 70 megs in size so clearly we're not using all
of the all of the binary code that's available in the framework
uh we're we're going to take questions at the end if you don't mind good thanks
so next i just wanted to um just highlight the code that bob just reviewed and then contrast that with the the
android or just show the equivalent code in android and that you know it's it's pretty much the you know the same level of coding
um in either environment and so you can see the first line is showing that creation of the client the s3 client
and that's a pattern for any service that you use with their sdks you'll have to create a client first
and so you'll you'll see that when we show some other code as well once you have that client you can then
execute any um any you know operation against the service so you can see that in the next
line where you see the the creating of an s3 bucket and again a single line of code you know
using the client and you just create the bucket you give it the name you want to create now the way s3 works is um you don't
need to create a bucket each time you want to put data into into the bucket you would create the bucket once and then you would upload
objects and then you could download from from there um just for sake of completeness we're just showing the you know the full creation here the
next line shows putting objects into the into that bucket and again it's you know it's very simple to put
data up now into the cloud you can see it's just a few lines of code um you give it the the bucket name the
object name and and the data you want to store and then if you want to retrieve that that's the final line of code
you can see that you know you just create a get object request with you know what the name of the bucket you want to retrieve the object from and the
name of the object and you get back the data and you can see that for ios and android it's very similar and very simple to do
that and one of the things you know one of the reasons for this is that the sdks
there's a lot going under the covers that's happening the sdk is you know marshaling the request it's unmarshalling the response
it's signing the request it's handling any errors and you know we'll give you back an exception or an error
if it runs into a problem we'll do automatic retry so the sdks are doing a lot for you and trying to simplify the work that you
would need to do so you can focus more on your application and business logic rather than you know integrating and connect you
know communicating with the cloud
so another uh another sample that we include with the
sdks is called our message board sample and what that highlights
is amazon sqs and amazon sns which are the simple queue service and simple notification service
and that that enables for setting up of cues where you can you can have um you know messages put into the queue and
then there you know it acts as a you know as a queue in the cloud and for for the notification service
you can subscribe people and they can receive notifications via you know a text message or an email or they can
you can actually even connect a cue to um to notifications to a topic you
would create a topic and then you send messages to that topic and then anybody who subscribed to that
topic would receive those notifications and so we have a sample the we're not going to demo it but
if you were to download the sdks you could you could try it out um and we have an article that goes along with it that details the code and
it shows how you can run the sample and how it's communicating and working with the different services to implement this application
but next i wanted to talk about another another sample we include we have a lot of samples in
our on in our sdks we have eight i believe in them in total and and if they use various services and try to

uh the various services for your application but another another service we support is the amazon ses service or the simple email service
and this allows you to send email from your application without having to interface with the you
know with without having to interface with your the mail app so you know you don't have to leave your application and go to the mail
the mail application on the phone except for the user to send an email instead you can just send email behind the scenes and this this could be good for
you know sending feedback to you or capturing errors or things of that sort

so next um another sample actually in this in this case we have a couple of different samples that we provide in the
sdks is to support amazon dynamodb amazon dynamodb is a nosql database
and with that actual service we we have two types of interfaces in each of the sdks we have what we call our low-level
interface which is a one-to-one mapping of the
of the um of the operations uh available to you by the service so amazon you know
dynamodb has create table list tables put item get item operation
so you'll see those same operations in the low-level sdk service that we provide the low-level
interface that we provide in each of the sdks but for each of the each of the environments for the ios sdk we have a
high level interface that we call the aws persistent framework for core data so it's a core data implementation that
that allows you to use core data and then goes to and stores your data in dynamodb and for
android we have a dynamodb mapper that allows you again to work in a like at an object level instead of working at a
functional level you can work in an object level to then store your data in dynamodb
so for each of these different interfaces we have a sample and an article that details
um some code and an application that you could you know you could use to jump start your own development
and and give specifics on on how it works um also i'd like to mention is that tomorrow
bob is going to be giving a talk specifically about the two high-level interfaces and going into a
lot more detail of how they work and how you can use them and doing some demos there as well so if you wanna
if you wanna learn more about those interfaces in dynamodb you can go to that talk which is tomorrow
okay next i just want to mention i just wanted to talk about managing credentials
so so as you saw through our samples to to make you know to make these requests
against the services you have to have these credentials an access key and a secret key and
in a mobile environment you know it's a little bit of a different environment because the uh the application is actually
running in the user's hands so one of the things is you know how do you get the the credentials in
into the device so one thing is you don't want to embed your root credentials into your application code
and then deliver that as a as your application um if it were to get compromised if the if
the keys were to be extracted your your entire aws account would be accessible and it is it is easy for
information to be extracted from applications so that's that's not a recommended practice
so so one thought if you're familiar with aws you may know about um iam accounts and what that is it's essentially like a
sub account from your your main root uh account and what one thing you can do in there is you can set up
permissions and you can limit the scope of that account so i'm showing a policy um
in this slide that effectively says you know it's going to allow the user to put objects into s3 and get
objects from s3 but only in a specific bucket in a bucket you know an s3 bucket called my
bucket and so you can put these these uh this policy onto the im account
and that would limit the scope of what that account can do so if that account would not be able to call ec2 or dynamo or do anything else would
not be able to create new buckets it could only be able to do these operations on that bucket and you might think that
you can embed these credentials into your application but again this has this has a problem as well first off you can't rotate the
credentials once it's in the app if you were to rotate the credentials that app would no longer function
because it's now using credentials that are no longer valid and then secondly um
there's no individual user control so the problem there is if you find somebody's being malicious with your app
you can't just specifically turn them off you'd have to turn off the entire app so that that's not um it's still too limited so
obviously what should you do so one thing what we've done is we've
created what we call a token vending machine
which is a which we provide as a sample reference application and what this helps you do is to get
temporary um time limited uh credentials into into applications and so the way this
works is your device your application would you know connect to the tvm the tvm would authenticate it
and then send back the temporary credentials to the device that it would then use to make calls against aws and then those
temporary credentials you know would only last from 1 to 36 hours and would again be limited like i was showing in the um the im use
case that this slide before so that that would limit you know what what they would do but this is a reference application that you know
we we provide the code and documentation on how you can run it and update it to meet your application
needs um and then this is a way that your apps could connect to to get credentials in a more secure more secure um method
um so to summarize you know don't embed credentials into your application we have some art articles and and
documents discussing how the tvm works and and why you want to use that instead of embedding your credentials and also
we provide a full um application that uses a custom tvm it takes the you know
the the the code that we provide and then customizes it for a specific application
that we show and we're gonna actually demo that uh shortly but it would it would walk you through both an ios and an android case
of how you could do that for an application

thanks bob so as bob was mentioning the uh the way that magic happens is
again is it is a policy um that's applied to the credentials so when the tvm when the when a user logged in when vegas one was
logging in um and the and credentials were being generated for that user and being sent back a policy was was uh
applied to the credentials to limit what you know to specify exactly what those credentials could do and that
policy is listed here so again you can see if you look at the there's two statements um so two
actions that the the credentials have so if you look at the first one it's allowing put get and delete object on a
particular uh resource which is s3 and it's that reinvent personal file store bucket that bob was just highlighting um
and then it has this username string now the tvm what it's doing is it's substituting the username that was
logged in so vegas one was logged in and it was substituted for username here um so that's why when you look
in the console you saw those the two subfolders vegas one and vegas two
um because those were substituted in so vegas one could only put get and delete objects within that
subfolder um and when vegas two logs in he can only do it for his his username the second statement is
allowing is allowing the user to to list to list the bucket to list the objects within
that bucket but again it's saying it can only do it on the on the one particular bucket the reinvent personal file store bucket
and it has to be prefixed with the username so that limits it again to that to that subfolder
so as bob was mentioning if the credentials were still extracted from the mobile application um
they would only be able to access that single bucket and only those only those operations so
you would not be able to start ec2 instances you would not be able to access dynamodb you would not be able to create additional buckets or anything of that
sort so that's that's the way the token vending machine can can limit what you can do and the way
the token vending machine does that is it uses a service called sts or the secure token
service to create these temporary credentials and apply a policy to it glenn mention the fact that they're
temporary so one other thing with that is those credentials are temporary
and that the you can specify how long they're good for so you can you can specify that they're only good for one to 36 hours um and then that allows
you with the token vending machine to if you find a user as being malicious you can then not authenticate them
through the tvm anymore and then they won't be able to get new credentials so i just wanted to um so just summarize
